article.text: If you read my Redmi Note 6 Pro review, you will know that I was getting tired of the Redmi Note series’s same old design. Ever since the Redmi Note 3, the series had a metal body that looked about the same every generation. Thankfully, Xiaomi switched to a glass body with the Redmi Note 7.

So yes, this article is all about the Redmi Note 7, successor to the Redmi Note 6 Pro. (What happened to the Redmi Note 6 though?) Is it worth getting? How does it compare to the competition, or even Xiaomi’s own POCO F1? Should you get the Redmi Note 7? Let’s find out.
Pricing has yet to be announced, but I am expecting it to cost around S$320 for this 64/4GB variant.
128GB ROM + 4GB RAM @ S$369 (Pacific City stores only)
Design & Display – A New Era of Redmi

Redmi Note 7 has 3 “firsts” in a Redmi device. First of these “first” is no other than the glass body design. The glass on the front and rear are both Gorilla Glass 5, so you can be assured about their quality. It comes in 3 beautiful colors: Space Black, Neptune Blue and Nebula Red.

My review unit is Neptune Blue and its gradient transitions from dark violet on top to azure blue at the bottom. It looks fabulous! Despite the glass design, fingerprints are barely noticeable on it, so it looks good all the time. It seems as if Xiaomi used a special coating for this.
The second “first” is that new “Redmi by Xiaomi” logo on the bottom. Redmi is now officially a brand on its own! Lastly, this is the first globally available Redmi device with USB Type C. Finally!

While the glass rear’s sides fo not curve like its predecessors, it still manages to feel nice in the hand. The camera protrudes quite a bit, even with the included clear case on, so it does not sit flat on a table. On top, we still have an audio jack and IR blaster. The SIM tray has a nano SIM slot and a hybrid slot.

On the front is a 6.3″ FHD+ IPS LCD display with a 19.5:9 ratio. Its bezels are about as large as the POCO F1, but the notch is much smaller, housing only a single selfie camera. This display is very bright, has pleasing colors and great viewing angles; It is a great display for the price.

Redmi Note 7 has a notification light below the display, but it is in a really odd position. I wish it was centered, but it probably wasn’t possible due to space constraints. There isn’t a dedicated proximity sensor, with the camera taking over its role instead. However, I find it to be not very reliable.
Performance – Back to Upper Snapdragon 6xx Series!

Back in 2016, Redmi Note 3 made headlines when it was announced that it came with the Snapdragon 650 processor. Xiaomi then moved to the lower 6xx series with following devices due to supposedly lower power consumption. Things are changing again with the Redmi Note 7.

Powering Redmi Note 7 is the Snapdragon 660 processor. It may be close to 2 years old now, but it is still really powerful. Playing PUBG Mobile on medium graphics, game play was butter smooth other than some occasional frame drops. Asphalt Legends ran without a hitch on high quality.

The device fared well in benchmarks too. AnTuTu gave it a score of 136264. Meanwhile, it scored 1634 for single-core and 5123 for multi-core in Geekbench 4. A noticeable improvement over its predecessor.

Redmi Note 7 uses Samsung’s GM1 sensor for its main camera on the rear. It is claimed to be 48 MP, but that isn’t entirely true; it splits each of the 12 MP pixel into 4 via interpolation. We shall test how much difference 48MP makes in a while. There is also a secondary 5 MP sensor for depth sensing.

In the day, photos turn out great, like almost every other smartphones these days. Colors are pretty accurate, they look a little over-saturated on the phone’s display. At night though is when it really shines. Even without night mode, photos turn out with little noise while still retaining some details.

Only when it gets really dark then you need to use night mode. It uses long exposure to take in a lot more light and it works well as long as you do not shake too much. Photos taken with it can look a little unnatural at times. Still, better than taking a completely dark photo full lot of noise.
L – Without Night Mode, R – With Night Mode
L – Without Night Mode, M – With Night Mode, R – With Google Night Sight

Now, to the part you have been waiting for: 48MP photos. It is only available in Pro mode, via a toggle on top. Look at the comparison below. Zooming in on the clouds, the 48MP photo has slightly more details, but definitely not 4 times more. So yeah, not true 48MP good, but better than 12MP.
L – 12 MP Cropped, R – 48 MP Cropped
For videos, the Redmi Note 7 can shoot up to 1080p 60fps, no 4K. Apart from being a little shaky, it seems to be doing quite well at recording videos in the day. (Refer to video review above)
Front Camera – Nothing Out of the Ordinary

As you may have inferred from the title, the 13MP selfie camera on the Redmi Note 7 doesn’t bring much surprises. As with most selfie cameras, it suffers from dynamic range and colors often turn out a little pale. That said, it is still a respectable front facing camera.
The same thing for videos. Dynamic range is lacking, but I do like the fact that it doesn’t try to over-sharpen the video. (Again, refer to video review for sample video)

There are 2 speaker grills on the bottom, but on the right one houses the speaker. POCO F1’s speakers sounds richer and slightly louder, but the Redmi Note 7 does a decent job in a non-noisy environment.
In noisy environments however, you will want to plug in a pair of headphones instead. And yes, the Redmi Note 7 has a headphone jack so you do not need Bluetooth earphones.
Battery Life – Great, But Not 4000mAh Great

Battery life have gotten worse after every iteration since Redmi Note 4. Thankfully, Redmi Note 7 seems to be as good or greater at endurance than its predecessor. With moderate to intensive usage, I was able to end the day with 8% battery, with 5h 11min of screen-on time.
Usage: 2h PUBG Mobile, 1h 13min Chrome, 30min Facebook, 45min music playback

Originally, I didn’t want to include this section. Afterall, I have already covered MIUI numerous times. But coming from the POCO F1, which is ad-free, using MIUI with ads feels less enjoyable. However, I noticed that Xiaomi removed ads that appear when you open a MIUI default app. Nice!

Lei Jun recently talked about reworking their ad model, so hopefully they will make them less intrusive. That said, MIUI is still one of the best Android skins available right now if you can look past the ads. Redmi Note 7 runs MIUI 10.2 on top of Android 9 Pie out of the box.

Should you get the Redmi Note 7, or pay a bit more for the POCO F1? That will depend on what you use your phone for. If you are a gamer who needs the smoothest gaming experience, or if you need a long lasting battery, then POCO F1 would be the obvious answer.
But for most users who do not really game, the Redmi Note 7’s performance will do. It has a much nicer glass body design and the notch is much smaller so you can see more.
What I Would like to See

I must say that I am really impressed with what Xiaomi has done with the Redmi Note 7. It is the biggest update to the series yet, and I can’t wait to see how the Redmi brand will evolve now that it is an actual sub-brand. There are still a few ways Xiaomi can improve the Redmi Note series.

Firstly, I would like to see Xiaomi bring the ad-free model to Redmi devices. The POCO F1 isn’t much more expensive than the Redmi Note 7. If it can be ad-free, why can’t the Redmi Note series also be ad-free? I wouldn’t mind paying S$10-S$20 more for no more ads.

Secondly, I wish Xiaomi would do some optimization for better battery life. Despite keeping the battery 4000mAh, Redmi Note series’s battery life have decreased significantly over the year. How is it that the POCO F1, with better performance and same battery size, can last almost twice as long?

Lastly, Xiaomi included a free clear case, but they did not pre-apply a screen protector. Perhaps it is a cost saving measure, but most people are going to get one anyway, so why not include one? I am sure most consumers do not mind paying an additional dollar or two for a pre-applied screen protector.
(Instead of getting it at shops that charge S$5 to S$10)
